MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Official Greeting Cards.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the cost of official greeting cards sent by him and his Parliamentary Secretary at Christmas, 1974; and whether the cards were of Irish manufacture.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The cost of official greeting cards sent by me and by my Parliamentary Secretary was £80.00 and £31.47 respectively. The cards were of Irish manufacture.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: The Minister did not send me one.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I will remember that this year.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Education Department Report.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the date of publication of the next report of the Department of Education (Statistics and Work).

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: It is expected that the next statistical report of the Department will be available by October, 1975.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Does the Minister intend to expand the report from purely statistics to the old format which included statistics and work?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: There are no present plans to change the format of the report. The decision to change it was made in the middle sixties, as the Deputy knows, and no decision has been made to change that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Was it envisaged at the time the change was made that the report would be made separately and more fully?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Separately, yes; more fully, I presume so.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Will it be made separately then in the form of the published report?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The normal form of publication of statistics. It is separate from the annual report which used to be published and is not published any more.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Considering the amount of innovation, the change in curricula and so on, would the Minister consider it wise to have such a report again?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I am sure it would be very nice to have it but there are no present plans to have one.
Question No. 6 postponed.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Remedial Teachers' Courses.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Power Mr. Power
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will arrange that the in-service courses for remedial second level teachers will be continued during the coming year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I will do my best to arrange accordingly but as I have already indicated the total provision for in-service courses is very much reduced in the present financial year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Do I take it that the amount now available is about £12,000?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Yes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Does the Minister seriously think that any kind of course can be run on that kind of money?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Obviously, some courses can be run on the money.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: What is the Minister's estimate of the number of people who can be dealt with for that sum?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: That would be a specific about which I would need to be advised particularly. For obvious reasons it will not be on the same scale as previous years.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Could the Minister give us an indication of his estimate of the number of teachers who should be put through “in-service” courses?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Of a particular nature?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: What would the Minister regard as the ideal number to put through such a course every year so that ultimately we would get somewhere with this problem? Would the Minister relate that to the number of courses being provided this year? In other words, could the Minister give us some indication of what progress is being made with the problem?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Up to the present, that is over a number of years past, 160 teachers have taken this course and the number at present completing the training is 73, making a total of 233 out of approximately 9,000 to 10,000 teachers. That is the rate of progress we are making at present. Obviously, it is desirable to speed this up but, unfortunately, we cannot do it this year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Would the Minister agree with the statistic of roughly 25 per cent intake to post-primary schools as being the percentage needing remedial work? If so, would the Minister not agree that one-quarter of the teaching force at least should have this type of training?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I would so agree. I would even say it was as high as one-third in some cases. Nobody need doubt my position in this matter.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Teacher's Earnings and Taxes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he has received an application from a person (name supplied) in County Limerick for a statement of his gross earnings and taxes paid over the last six years; and the reasons for the refusal to supply this statement.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Details of gross earnings and tax deductions are shown on the monthly salary cheques issued to teachers and should, in this way, be known to the teacher in question.

The preparation of a separate statement covering a period of six years would not normally be warranted in view of the considerable amount of official time involved in going back on payment records. However, as an exceptional matter and having regard to the special circumstances related to this individual case, I have given a direction that the statement be prepared and forwarded to the teacher as soon as possible.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Thank you, Minister.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kenneally Mr. Kenneally
Speaker.P: May I take it, then, that if I put down a question here I will be afforded the same facilities as the person involved?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: That is a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: The Deputy cannot. He can ask me.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Travelling and Subsistence Allowances.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Browne Mr. Browne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education why the increases granted to members of local authorities in travelling and subsistence allowances have not been applied to members of vocational education committees.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Under the Vocational Education Acts a statutory instrument is necessary to give legal effect to increases in travelling and subsistence allowances payable to members of vocational education committees for attendance at meetings. The increases referred to in the Deputy's question have been authorised by me and the necessary steps are being taken regarding the preparation of the statutory instrument in this case.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Browne Mr. Browne
Speaker.P: Will the increases apply to the date already granted so far as these increases are concerned to members of other public bodies, county councils, boards of health and so on? I am asking the Minister if the increases will be retrospective to the same date as was granted to members of other local authorities?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: That is a matter on which I would prefer not to be pressed at this stage. I would hope it would be but I do not want to give any guarantee.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: Can the Minister state why county vocational committees are not included for travelling and subsistence allowances?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Because the Vocational Education Act has no specific provision so to extend it. I am seeking advice in regard to that particular matter on a legal basis.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: How soon might the Minister have some information in this respect?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: That depends on the person from whom I am seeking the legal advice. I am sure it will not be delayed too long.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Parliamentary Secretary's Duties.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will give an assurance that the recent assignment of additional duties as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry and Commerce to his Parliamentary Secretary will not mean a diminution in the importance attached to sport and recreation; if he will state a date by which his Parliamentary Secretary may be expected to return to wholetime duties with special responsibility for sport and recreation in his Department; and if he will make a policy statement on physical education in the context of the development of the National College of Physical Education in Limerick.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I do give the assurance sought by the Deputy and, in the light of that, I would ask him to accept that the assumption of additional duties does not lessen the importance which the Parliamentary Secretary attaches to his special responsibility for sport and recreation.

In the matter of policy in regard to physical education it is, of course, intended to continue encouraging its development in our schools and colleges and supporting the important contribution which the National College of Physical Education makes to that development.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: Can the Minister state what portion of the Parliamentary Secretary's time now is spent on sport and recreation activities?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Sufficient to perform the duties with his customary assiduity.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: That means none.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Has the Minister changed the regulation with regard to recognition of time spent by teachers on sport and recreation in vocational schools?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: That is a separate matter, Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: I submit, a Cheann Comhairle, it arises directly from the question, the importance of sport and recreation.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The duties of the Parliamentary Secretary are involved.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Could the Minister say, with regard to the National College of Physical Education in Limerick, whether his Department approached any of the universities with a view to having them confer a degree on the graduates of the National College of Physical Education?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Yes, an approach was made.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: To how many university colleges?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: To the university college in whose area, under the Act, the college lies.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: What was the result of the approach?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: It was not successful as of this time.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Mayo School.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education his plans in relation to Lisaniska national school, Knockmore, Ballina, County Mayo.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Following recent investigation of the reorganisation of the schools in the parish, it is proposed to amalgamate Lisaniska and two other schools, Shraheen and Cloghans, in a central school at Curraboggan, when the necessary extension to Curraboggan national school has been provided.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: Were the parents of Lisaniska national school consulted about this?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: It would seem from the notes available to me that the agreement of the manager was forthcoming. I am not in a position to say what is the position in regard to the parents but I would presume that the manager was speaking on their behalf when making this approach to the Department.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: Would the Minister now accept my word that the manager was not speaking on behalf of the parents and that the parents do not want Lisaniska national school closed? Would the Minister further accept that the original proposition for a central school was to put it in the village of Knockmore, that the parents now want some repairs carried out to Lisaniska national school and want consultation with the Department?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I have replied to the Deputy that it is proposed to amalgamate the school with two other schools and I have not been given any reasons to depart from that decision.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: Many times in this House the Minister has told us that his policy is one of consultation. I am now asking him for consultation with these parents, who were not consulted, and who I am sure are very concerned about an arbitrary decision to close the school?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I would not regard the decision as arbitrary in view of what I have told the Deputy and the House already, that when the manager called to the Department he was agreeable to centralisation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: Further arising out of the Minister's reply——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I have called the next question. I have allowed Deputy Calleary some considerable latitude. He must obey the Chair at some stage.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: It is very seldom the Deputy worries the Chair.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Deputy has been given sufficient latitude on this question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: Will the Minister have an inspector call to consult with the parents of children attending Lisaniska national school? It is a simple question and a simple answer should be given to it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I am afraid I cannot give the Deputy that assurance. The decision has been made.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - County Roscommon School.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when repairs will be carried out to Brusna national school, Ballaghaderreen, County Roscommon.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The Commissioners of Public Works have recently advised the reverend manager as to the carrying out of necessary works at Brusna NS, Ballaghaderreen, County Roscommon. I am not in a position to say when the works will commence.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Mayo Schools.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will permit Knocks national school, Killasser, Swinford, County Mayo to remain open.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The Department is fully satisfied that the educational interests of the pupils of both Killasser and Knocks Schools could best be served by closing Knocks national school and by establishing a transport service to convey the children concerned to Killasser national school. It has, accordingly, been decided to close Knocks national school on 30th June, 1975.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: In this case the Minister is aware that an inspector visited Knocks national school and that the vast majority of the parents want the school kept open. Would the Minister not now accede to the wishes of the parents in this case?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: As the Deputy will know, the Department do not necessarily automatically accept parents' objections. The Department have to assess the worth of the objections. The parents' objections have been considered but they do not outweigh other considerations in the matter and, therefore, I cannot give the Deputy the assurance he seeks.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: Will the Minister let us know what are the other considerations? Quite a number of extensions will be needed at Killasser national school, to the actual school and to the playground area which is totally inadequate. There is a good school at Knocks. Will the Minister not allow that school to remain open?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The Deputy asked me for some of the considerations. First, it is a one-teacher school with a declining average: secondly, there is an empty classroom in the Killasser school; thirdly, the Killasser building is in better shape having central heating and flush toilets whereas the school at Knocks still has dry toilets; fourthly, the new curriculum can be put into operation in the amalgamated three-teacher school. There are other considerations also.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: The Deputy is aware of the other considerations. They cannot be mentioned in this House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will agree with the decision of the parents and allow Creevagh national school, Carramore, Lacken, Ballina, County Mayo to remain open.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: As I explained in my reply to the Deputy on 15th November, 1974, the amalgamation of Creevagh and Carramore schools, to form a three-teacher unit, would, it is considered, be to the educational advantage of the pupils concerned.

Creevagh school building has been recommended for replacement and, as it is a small two-teacher school, grants would not be available for this purpose. Consideration is being given, in consultation with the school manager, to the question of providing an additional classroom at Carramore in order to effect the amalgamation of these two schools.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: In this instance the Minister received from me the signatures of all the parents of the pupils attending Creevagh national school requesting that the school remain open. Would the Minister not abide by the wishes of the parents, as he has frequently said in this House? Further, will he let me know if the manager has written requesting that the school remain open? There is a new manager in the school.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: What the Deputy says is correct. I have personally been involved in this case. As there are long-term proposals for reorganisation in the parish, we will bear in mind the representations of the manager and the parents. We still consider our proposal for amalgamation is the best one in the situation but we are not prepared to go to the stake for it at this point.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education his plans in relation to Tauneena national school, Charlestown, County Mayo.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The question of the reorganisation of the school facilities in this parish is at present being considered. A decision has not yet been taken in the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: Would the Minister consider asking an inspector to call to discuss the matter with the parents? After a meeting held recently they asked me to convey that request to the Minister.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The inspector is closely in touch with the school in question and he is advising the Department. If the Deputy can advance any reasons why an inspector should go specifically to this area I should like to hear them.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: As £2,000 was spent on the school two years ago, the parents would like an inspector to come and discuss the matter with them.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I will give consideration to the Deputy's suggestion in view of the Department's advice already received in the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he has sanctioned plans for the extension to Ballina vocational school, County Mayo.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: An outline plan for this extension has been submitted by the vocational education committee. Because of the nature of the site it has been found necessary to undertake a special study in order to decide the most economic approach to the next phase of building. It is hoped that the results of this study will be available soon and plans can then be finalised.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: Did the Minister say one plan had been received?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Yes. The VEC have already submitted an outline plan showing the approach favoured by them.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: Will the Minister state if the VEC also submitted a report from a quantity surveyor saying the plan submitted by the VEC was the cheaper of the two plans prepared by the architect?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Because of the nature of the terrain it is necessary for the VEC to initiate a feasibility study. I understand this feasibility study will be completed shortly and submitted. I have not yet received it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: Will the Minister state if the guarantee that work would start in late 1975 still holds?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: We are aiming for the end of 1975 but in view of the delay, which was not caused necessarily by my Department, it might be better to say early 1976.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - County Roscommon Schools' Grants.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Gibbons Dr. Gibbons
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the increase in grants he has sanctioned under the free education schemes for (a) St. Mary's College Complex, Boyle and (b) the post-primary schools in Roscommon; the date on which they will be payable; and whether they will be retrospective to 1st September, 1974.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The increase in grants which has been sanctioned under the free education scheme is £5 per pupil and it is operative with effect from the beginning of the 1974-75 school year in the case of all post-primary schools.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Gibbons Dr. Gibbons
Speaker.P: Does the Minister accept that amount is sufficient to meet the commitments of the schools at present?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: It has been represented to me by numerous deputations that it is not.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Gibbons Dr. Gibbons
Speaker.P: Has the Minister anything further to offer them?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I have given the House an indication of a Government decision to increase the grants.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Before June?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Would the Deputy try to pin me to June?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Yesterday the Minister said it would be before June.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: We might even beat that.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Roscommon Education Proposals.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Gibbons Dr. Gibbons
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the proposals he has for (a) the building of primary schools (b) the provision of additions to primary schools (c) the provision of additions to post-primary schools (d) the provision of extra teachers to reduce pupil-teacher ratios in both primary and post-primary schools (e) the provision of extra finance for the running of post-primary schools as requested by parents and the Catholic Headmasters' Association, in County Roscommon; if he has made any decisions during recent weeks on those proposals; and, if so, if they will all be implemented before the end of the current financial year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: In relation to (a) and (b), primary school buildings, the position is that there are at present 114 new schools and 61 extension schemes in progress and a further 132 new schools and extensions are at advanced planning stages and could begin before the end of the current financial year.

In regard to (c), post-primary building, I have already given particulars of 60 major projects for 1975 in reply to Question No. 32 on 15th November, 1974. In regard to (d), extra teachers for primary and post-primary schools, I have already indicated in Question No. 41 of 29th April, 1975, that I will be making a statement at an early date in regard to the matter when examination of it has been completed. In regard to (e), extra finance for post-primary schools in County Roscommon, I am not yet in a position to add anything to the statement which I made on this matter generally in connection with the motion in this House on 16th April, 1975.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: It may be that this answer was formulated before the Minister spoke yesterday, but certainly he added something substantial to his statement yesterday, in reply to the motion. Would the Minister agree this is so?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: That I answered more fully today than yesterday?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: The Minister has stated he is not in a position to add to the answer he gave to the motion on the financing of secondary schools but yesterday, under questioning in the House, he said that the payments would be made before June. This does not accord with what the Minister has read out now.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The Deputy will realise I refused to be pinned. I hope it would be so and if he consults the Official Record he will find that is broadly the position.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - School Transport Service.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will extend the school bus service from Moylisha Cross to Glen Cross, where there is a turning area for a bus, to collect two children (details supplied) in County Carlow to attend Clonegal national school.

Speaker.hpid: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Mr. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.NameTxt: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Mr. Bruton)
Speaker.P: An extension of the route as suggested by the Deputy is not feasible as the roads in the locality are regarded by CIE as too narrow and hazardous for the large bus which is engaged on this particular transport service.
I am having the matter further examined, however, to see if it may be possible to meet the transport problem in relation to these children in some other way.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: On 5th November the Parliamentary Secretary wrote to me on this matter. He is aware that the school which this child attended was closed and amalgamated with the school at Clonegal which is six miles from the child's home. At the moment the child has to travel 2.3 miles to reach the bus. Would the Parliamentary Secretary not accept that what I have offered here is a viable alternative?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: I agree with the statements made by the Deputy in the first part of his question. However, CIE who advise us on transport matters have stated the roads are too narrow for extension of the regular service to go nearer this family's house. However, I can assure the Deputy that I will do everything possible to find some other solution which is consistent with the advice of CIE to enable this family to get an improved service.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: In other words, this route will be examined?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: Every possible avenue will be examined.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education why school transport will not be provided for an 11-year-old boy (name supplied) in County Wicklow from Ashtown, Roundwood.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: The child in question is not eligible for free school transport as he resides only half a mile from Roundwood national school which is his nearest suitable school.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: I accept what the Parliamentary Secretary has said but is he aware that this boy previously lived in Bray and that his parents wished him to continue attending school there?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: The situation still obtains that this child lives only half a mile from Roundwood national school which is a perfectly good national school. As in the case of parents in any other situation if they want to send their children to any other school they are perfectly free to do so but it is to the nearest school that transport will be provided.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: This is all right in the case of situations which arise but ought not be a hard and fast rule in the case of existing situations. Would the Parliamentary Secretary bear in mind that the parents simply wanted continuity in the child's education? It means now that the child must wait in Bray town from 4 p.m. until 7 p.m. for a bus while the school bus which has seats available leaves Bray at 4 p.m. The Parliamentary Secretary will be aware that there is no shortage of numbers in Roundwood national school as Moneystown national school is going to be phased out——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Deputy is embarking on a speech.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: I hope I am not. I prefaced it with an interrogative.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: That is not sufficient.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: I am asking a question. As Moneystown national school is being phased out, does the Minister not think there are ample numbers in Roundwood and this should be a special case? Would he look into the matter again?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: If you start giving transport to children who are only half a mile from the nearest school to other schools in any case you cannot resist doing it in many others and that would lead to a chaotic situation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: Is it now the policy of the Department to reduce rather than increase the number of children being carried to national schools?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: This is a specific question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: It relates to school transport.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: It relates to a specific place and I will not allow an extension.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if school transport will be provided for a ten-year-old boy (name supplied) in County Carlow to Knockananna national school.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: The child in question would not normally be eligible for free transport to school as he is over 10 years of age and resides less than three miles from Knockananna national school. On medical grounds, however, facilities are at present being provided for him and these will be continued until summer, 1976, when the position will be reviewed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: When were those facilities provided?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: I have not got the date. I do not think it is very long ago.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: Would it have been within the last three weeks, since representations were made?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if school transport will be provided for three children of the same family (details supplied) to Kilcoole national school, County Wicklow.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: As the children in question reside less than two miles from the national schools in Kilcoole, they are not eligible for free transport under the conditions of the ordinary scheme. A claim that they would have attended Newcastle national school, which was amalgamated with the Kilcoole national school on 1st July, 1968, and as such are entitled to transport under the special arrangements applicable in amalgamation cases is being investigated, and I shall let the Deputy know the outcome in due course.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that those children should have had school transport prior to 1st November last year?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: I am informed that some members of the family had transport irregularly for some time while there was room on the bus but that this was due to a misunderstanding and to laxity on the part of some of the people directly involved. Their case for transport in a regular fashion is being investigated and I understand that an official of the Department will be visiting the area in about three weeks.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: The Parliamentary Secretary can close his brief on that as the family are now taking up residence elsewhere. However, there is the point that those children did not attend school from mid-November because of this transport problem.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Deputy is imparting information, not seeking it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: Both the Minister and the Parliamentary Secretary seem to have been quite lax on this.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cronin Mr. Cronin
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if, in view of the fact that the essential qualifications have been fulfilled, he will sanction a transport service to Buttevant national school, County Cork, from the Grange and Boherascrub areas.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: Since there are at present only nine children eligible for free school transport in the Grange and Boherascrub areas, the conditions necessary for the provision of a service under the free transport scheme do not exist. However, the position is being kept under continuing review and particular attention will be paid to the position likely to arise on 1st July at the start of the new school year. It is understood that there may be ten eligible children from the areas concerned attending Buttevant national school in July and if this proves to be so a service will then be established.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education why persons (names supplied) in County Limerick have not been deemed eligible for transport to the new national school in Abbeyfeale.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: I understand that this application was refused on the grounds that the children have transport facilities available to them to their nearest national school, Knocknasna national school.
However, in view of representations received, I am having inquiries made and I will communicate with the Deputy in the matter in due course.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that those children live in the catchment area of Springmount national school which has recently been closed and that the children in this catchment area are being provided with transport to the new national school in Abbeyfeale and that the three young children in question would seemingly be eligible for transport to the new national school in Abbeyfeale?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: When a school is closed and amalgamated with another free transport to the amalgamated school is provided for children who were bona fide on the rolls of the closed school and for those residing in the closed school area who could have been expected to have attended that school if it had remained open. It is the applicability of those conditions in the case of this family that is being investigated at present.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: When is it likely that the Parliamentary Secretary will have a decision on this matter? It has been going on for a number of weeks. If a little case like this takes so much time, there must be quite a backlog in the transport section of the Department.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: I will do everything I can to have it expedited.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: Regarding the measurement for school transport——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I am sorry to interrupt Deputy Allen but I want to bring to his notice that this question deals with a specific matter appertaining to Limerick and I will not allow an extension.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: How does the Ceann Comhairle know I am not asking a question about Limerick? He did not give me a chance to ask it.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: It is not a relevant question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: How do you know until I ask it?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Meaney Mr. Meaney
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will take steps to renew the transport service for Muinifluigh national school, Macroom, County Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: There is not, at present, a sufficient number of eligible children available in the locality in question to warrant the retention of the transport service to Muinifluigh national school under the terms of the free transport scheme. The position will be kept under review and should the required number of eligible children become available, the service will be reintroduced.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Meaney Mr. Meaney
Speaker.P: How many children in the area are considered eligible?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: Eight.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Meaney Mr. Meaney
Speaker.P: Would the Minister take cognisance of the fact that this is a very rural area situated at the foot of the Musheragh hills and because the service has been withdrawn those children are deprived of the chance of a proper education?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: The service was designed to cope with situations in rural areas such as this and if the minimum number of children is eligible, the service will be reintroduced.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Meaney Mr. Meaney
Speaker.P: The Parliamentary Secretary says the service was designed to cater for children such as those. I say this is an exceptional case. People in a very rural area are being deprived of their rights as citizens and the children are not getting the facilities that are due to them. The Department are penny-pinching. This is the third service I was successful in getting started that had been cut out in the last one-and-a-half years but the people will hit back hard.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: The rule is and has always been that there must be 10 eligible children available for the establishment of a service and there are only eight in this case at present.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Would the Parliamentary Secretary not consider bending the rules?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Meaney Mr. Meaney
Speaker.P: There are only eight because they will not extend the area as has happened in other areas. This is a disgraceful situation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education why children (names supplied) in County Tipperary are deprived of free transport to Cahir national school.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: In order to cater for children in the locality in question it would be necessary to institute a special transport service. Since there are only four children eligible for transport it would not be open to the Department under the terms of the school transport scheme to provide such a service.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: In view of the closure of Garryclogher national school, would the Parliamentary Secretary be prepared to reconsider the position?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: I do not think it would be possible to extend the Garryclogher route to cope with these children. There is no interconnecting road which would be suitable for the bus and, apparently, it would have to go all the way to Cahir and back again. This would be tantamount to a special service for these children.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: In view of the closure of the school referred to, these children are in the catchment area and, consequently, are they not entitled to free transport?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: I do not think these children are in the closed Garryclogher school area.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: They are.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: I shall have a look at the situation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: Would the Parliamentary Secretary consider the provision of a special transport service for these children? There are still some very young families in the area.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: My information as to what is the position conflicts with what Deputy Davern has said but having regard to his argument, I shall have the matter looked into again.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brennan Mr. Brennan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will reconsider his decision not to provide transport for children from the townland of Carrickatleave to Meentinadea national school, County Donegal.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: In order to warrant the provision of a transport service to a national school from a particular locality, the number of children eligible for free transport in that locality must be at least ten. In a recent survey of the Carrickatleave area no child was found to be eligible. Eligible children are those between four and ten years of age who have a distance of at least two miles to travel to the nearest suitable school while for children over ten years of age the minimum distance is three miles. Accordingly, the provision of a transport service to cater for this locality is not warranted under the terms of the scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brennan Mr. Brennan
Speaker.P: We are becoming tired of this stock reply. Is the Parliamentary Secretary prepared to admit that these rules are capable of being bent, that they have been bent in many cases particularly in relation to Protestant schools? Has he any knowledge of what is involved in the request I have made on behalf of the 12 children who must walk along a bleak lonely mountain road for a distance of more than two miles and three of whom are beginning school? If transport is not provided they will not be able to go to school. Other children who live closer to the school can avail of free transport. Is it not time that this whole question of measuring miles was changed——

Speaker.hpid: Deputies Deputies
Speaker.P: Hear, hear.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brennan Mr. Brennan
Speaker.P: ——and that the rule which we fixed at the beginning and which is flexible and subject to the discretion of the Minister be changed so as to allow transport for all children?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: Practically all the children in this case are less than two miles from the nearest school.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brennan Mr. Brennan
Speaker.P: That is not correct.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: Various exceptional circumstances might be put forward in respect of every school in Ireland but to operate a scheme in a proper manner one must abide by basic rules.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brennan Mr. Brennan
Speaker.P: The Parliamentary Secretary has not answered my question as to whether he would admit that the rule has been bent in many instances, that it is subject to the discretion of the Minister. Surely a case can be made for including children who must walk more than two miles on a bare mountain road.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Deputy is indulging in repetition.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: When there is accommodation on a school bus, children who are not eligible for free transport can be accommodated as fare-paying passengers. It is not possible to bend the rule in cases so as to suit people who are able to exert pressure in one quarter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Nolan Mr. Nolan
Speaker.P: Is it true that the Minister for Education informed CIE that there would be no extension of the free transport scheme, even in respect of those who qualify for it, because of the lack of finance in the Department?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Deputy is injecting new material into the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Would the Parliamentary Secretary agree that a review of the whole system of school transport be carried out quickly?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: This is an extension of a specific question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, I wish to raise on the Adjournment the subject matter of Question No. 34 of 29th April, 1975.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Chair will communicate with the Deputy.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Garda-in-Service Training School.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice why the Garda-in-Service Training School in Dublin was closed at Christmas; if it has yet been reopened; and, if not, why.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Lands (Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick, Cavan) (for the Minister for Justice) Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Cavan) (for the Minister for Justice): The Commissioner of the Garda Síochána has informed me that training had to be suspended in the in-service training school in December, primarily because of pressing demands on Garda manpower and Garda services. It is the intention that either this training scheme or some variation of it will be resumed when the manpower situation permits. Meanwhile, the merits of various methods of providing such training will be examined fully either by the management consultants or otherwise.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: First, let me express the hope that the Minister for Justice is having an enjoyable time in the Seanad. Is the Minister saying that the Garda are understaffed?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I am not saying that but I am saying they are under pressure.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: Can the Minister give one good reason as to why the in-service training school is being closed?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I have stated and I repeat——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: All we were given was waffle.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan):——that it was necessary to suspend the school due to demands on manpower.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Garda Uniforms.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the reason for the delay of nearly one year in the issue of uniforms to the Garda.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Power Mr. Power
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if all outstanding uniforms have now been issued to the Garda; and if the usual issue of uniforms will be completed this year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 29 and 30 together.

I understand that several factors contributed to the delay in the issuing of made-up uniforms over the last 12 months. These included delays in the delivery of the material and insignia and delays in having the material made up.

MainHeading.P: Most members have now received the current uniform issue and the Post Office Stores say that they understand from the contractor there will be no delay in the delivery of the next issue, which is due to commence this year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: Would the Minister not agree that the delay is due to the Government being broke?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): No, but I would agree that there have been delays and that these occurred in the contractors' sphere of operation. I am assured that there will be no further delays.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Garda Task Force.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Carter Mr. Carter
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the number of gardaí he proposes to allocate to each unit of the task force to investigate and control crime in and about the city of Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): The assignment of members of the Force to particular duties or to particular units is a matter for the Garda themselves. The Commissioner has informed me that he considers that the present strength of the task force is adequate.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Tallaght (Dublin) Garda Station.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Walsh Mr. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if, in view of the heavy increase in the population of the Tallaght area, County Dublin, he will consider reopening Tallaght Garda Station on a 24-hour service basis.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): As the Deputy will recall, he and Deputy McMahon recently approached me about this matter and I agreed to convey their representations to the Commissioner. The Commissioner informed me that the matter was already under review as a result of various representations from community associations and it has been decided that the station will open on a 24-hour basis within the next week.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Cork City Garda Station.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. French Mr. French Mr. Healy Mr. Healy Mr. Wyse Mr. Wyse Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch
Speaker.NameTxt: Mr. J. Lynch, Mr. Wyse, Mr. Healy
Speaker.P: and Mr. French asked the Minister for Justice if he is aware of the need for a Garda station in the Gurranebraher/Churchfield area of Cork city; and when it is proposed to set up such a station.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): A major reorganisation of the Garda districts in Cork city has been recommended by the research and planning unit of the Garda Síochána. The scheme proposed would involve the erection of several new stations.

Before a final decision is taken on such a major scheme it will be necessary to take into account any relevant recommendations which may be made by management consultants who are presently discharging an assignment in relation to the Garda. I cannot say at this stage how soon it may be possible to make a decision.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wyse Mr. Wyse
Speaker.P: Is it not true that more than two years ago the overall position was reviewed regarding the gardaí in Cork city?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): It is true that recommendations were made with regard to the overall position in Cork city some time ago and that those recommendations would involve major reorganisation, as I said in the reply. That is being looked into at the moment by consultants and it would be inappropriate to make a statement until their expert advice has been received.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wyse Mr. Wyse
Speaker.P: This is an extraordinary state of affairs. We understood that expert advice was sought two years ago and a strong recommendation was made to the Minister for the establishment of Garda stations in a number of areas——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: A question please, Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wyse Mr. Wyse
Speaker.P: ——including the area referred to in the question. Do I take it from the Minister that there will be another investigation prior to the implementation of the recommendations made two years ago?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): It is not correct to say that these submissions were made to the Minister or the Department two years ago. Much more recently recommendations were made and they are now being studied in depth by the consultants and, on receipt of their advice, a decision will be taken.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Tallaght Garda Patrol Car.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Walsh Mr. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if, in view of the heavy increase in population in the Tallaght area, County Dublin, he will consider providing an extra patrol car to deal specially with this area.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): The Commissioner informs me that he considers that the present allocation of official transport at Tallaght, as supplemented by assistance from the district headquarters at Rathfarnham, is adequate for the needs of the area and he does not propose to increase it for the time being. The situation will be kept under review.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: Has the Garda patrol car been bringing in above the average number of prosecutions?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): That would seem to be a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Walsh Mr. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the number of prosecutions taken as a result of the activity of the Garda patrol car at the Old Bawn Road, Tallaght, County Dublin, during recent weeks.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): Summonses have been entered in sixteen cases for breaches of the speed limit during the period of 15th March to 22nd April, 1975, at Old Bawn Road, Tallaght.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Tallaght Gardaí.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Walsh Mr. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the number of gardaí attached to Tallaght Garda Station, County Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): The present strength of Tallaght Garda Station is three sergeants and 15 gardaí.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Walsh Mr. Walsh
Speaker.P: Can the Minister say that the strength of the Garda in this station will be increased, or is this under review?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I am glad to be able to tell the Deputy that the strength of the Garda at that station will be increased in the immediate future by the assignment of four extra gardaí.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Gun Licences.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Browne Mr. Browne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the number of punt gun licences held at present (a) in the State and (b) in County Wexford.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): Firearm certificates are issued by the Garda Síochána and, accordingly, the available figures relate to Garda districts.
The number of punt guns in the State in respect of which firearm certificates are held is 21, of which 13 are in the Wexford Garda district.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Official Greeting Cards.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the cost of official greeting cards sent by him at Christmas, 1974; and whether the cards were of Irish manufacture.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I did not send any.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Music Teaching Facilities.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Gibbons Dr. Gibbons
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if there are any facilities for teaching music to prisoners.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): Singing and the playing of musical instruments are taught in St. Patrick's Institution, in the Women's Prison in Dublin and in the open centres for juveniles.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Prisoner Employment.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Gibbons Dr. Gibbons
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the number of prisoners that are now gainfully employed; and the number of companies that co-operate with his Department in offering employment facilities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): In general, those prisoners in custody who are not in full-time attendance at educational classes are engaged in some form of work for a portion of the day, which, on average, is about five hours and a small gratuity is paid in respect of it. The task in which any particular person is engaged can be any one of a great variety and, of course, the number at work varies continuously for various reasons, including fluctuations in the prison population.

A number of prisoners are permitted to take employment outside the prison either on full or daily conditional release. It would be misleading to seek to put a figure on the number of firms who co-operate with my Department in the matter of giving employment to prisoners, either while they are serving their sentences or on their release. Very many firms have been helpful in this respect at various times over the years.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Prison Regulations.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Gibbons Dr. Gibbons
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he has any proposals for revising the Prison Regulations, 1947, in the near future.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): The revision of the rules for the government of prisons, 1947, is in hand but, unfortunately, because of pressure of urgent matters, it has not been possible to complete it. This will, however, be done as soon as circumstances permit.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Home Care Allowances.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Callanan Mr. Callanan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the proposals he has to provide money to health boards for payment of home-care allowances; if he is aware that the health boards cannot accept any more applications for home care as they have already overspent their allocations; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: I assume that the Deputy is referring to the home-help service in his question.

MainHeading.P: There is no question of any health board having overspent its 1975 allocation for this service. The final details of expenditure on the service in the current year have not yet been worked out and will be the subject of further discussions between officials of my Department and the health boards.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Callanan Mr. Callanan
Speaker.P: I am glad to hear the Minister say that. It contradicts what I have been told. I was told that one board exceeded their allocation for the year by £60,000. I was told there is some difficulty about the prescribed relative's allowance. It looked to me as if there was a complete shortage of money. I did not put down the question until I was told there was a shortage of money, that there is some difficulty with the officers who carry out the means test in relation to the prescribed relatives' allowance and that there have been delays of over two months in payments.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Question No. 43.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: Lest there may be any misunderstanding, it would be virtually impossible to spend a year's allocation in four months. The money has not run out. I think Deputy Callanan is on the Western Health Board?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Callanan Mr. Callanan
Speaker.P: Yes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: More money was provided this year for the home help service than was provided last year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Callanan Mr. Callanan
Speaker.P: That is not the point.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: The Deputy suggested that the money has run out. It has not.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Callanan Mr. Callanan
Speaker.P: I put down this question as a result of information I received.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: There may be more applicants than can be accommodated but more are being accommodated than there were last year.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Gibbons Dr. Gibbons
Speaker.P: Has the Minister issued any instructions to the health boards as to how those people should be defined and the conditions under which home help may be made available? If so, would he circulate those instructions?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: That seems to be a separate matter. Question No. 43.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: These are worked out between the officials of the Department of Health and the CEOs. So far as I am aware there has been no official communication.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Question No. 43.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Gibbons Dr. Gibbons
Speaker.P: Would the Minister agree that there are different attitude in different health boards?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: If that were the case I would try to ensure that there were the same standards for all the health boards.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gallagher Mr. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Arising out of... Minister's reply——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I have calls the next question a few times.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Accommodation For Aged.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Moore Mr. Moore
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he is satisfied that number of homes which care for people is adequate to meet demand; and if the standards in homes are adequate to ensure care for the residents.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: I am not satisfied the accommodation for the aged fully adequate to meet requirement but schemes have been in progress some years to provide extra accommodation and improve the facilitie for the aged throughout the country.

New geriatric units have been provided to replace old unsuitable premises, and others have been adapted and new extensions built. In all, some 4,200 beds in new or improved accommodation have been provided over the last nine years.

In addition, 48 new welfare homes, each with 40 beds, have been approved in principle. Of these, 18 are completed and in use, two are completed and about to be occupied, five will be ready for occupation this year or early next year, six are at tender stage and the remainder are at various stages of planning.

MainHeading.P: The standard of accommodation in the new geriatric units and the new welfare homes is very satisfactory. Accommodation is not so good in some of the older institutions but improvement schemes have been carried out at many centres in recent years, and this process is continuing.

Many old people are maintained in private geriatric homes of varying standards but, in general, they are of a reasonable standard and are inspected under the Health (Homes for the Incapacitated Persons) Act, 1964.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: Would the Minister agree that a badly needed number of hospital beds are being taken up by old people who would be better provided for in this type of home?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: I am so aware and I expressed my dissatisfaction with the situation in the first paragraph of my reply.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Callanan Mr. Callanan
Speaker.P: The question asked by Deputy Lemass is very relevant. I am sure the Minister will agree that home help is of vital importance. We should try to keep old people out of hospital and leave the beds available for those who really need them.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: I would not disagree with the Deputy and that is the effort.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leonard Mr. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if an assessment has been made recently of the merits of boarding out old people in private homes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: An assessment has been made in my Department of the merits of a scheme of boarding out old people in private homes.

Health boards are empowered to operate such a scheme under section 61 of the Health Act, 1970, and organised arrangements for the boarding out of elderly persons have been developed in Dublin and Westmeath. In Dublin, 23 such persons are boarded out with private families. In Westmeath, the number is 26.

MainHeading.P: Subject to careful placement procedures being used by health board staff and subject to regular inspection procedures being brought into operation to safeguard the interests of the elderly persons concerned, the scheme has merits. It offers an additional method of providing suitable accommodation for older members of our community and this is to be welcomed. It should, therefore, be seen as a service which is complementary to other, more traditional, methods of providing suitable accommodation for elderly people.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leonard Mr. Leonard
Speaker.P: In view of the problem of providing sufficient accommodation does the Minister propose asking other health boards to implement that?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: I believe other health boards are considering it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brennan Mr. Brennan
Speaker.P: Would the Minister consider urging others to do this and even offering better remuneration towards keeping those old people in private homes? Does the Minister agree that half the amount it takes to keep an old person in a home would be quite a satisfactory sum towards keeping that person in a private house?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: It would be cheaper to keep him in a private house.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brennan Mr. Brennan
Speaker.P: The person would be much happier.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: Naturally.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brennan Mr. Brennan
Speaker.P: Therefore, I am sure the Minister will encourage that scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leonard Mr. Leonard
Speaker.P: Has any assessment been made concerning the cost in a welfare home or in a private house?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: The overall cost or the individual cost?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leonard Mr. Leonard
Speaker.P: The individual cost.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: In Dublin it is a total of £14 per week and in Westmeath it is between £12 and £13 per week. There are figures for the cost of maintaining such a patient in an institution but I do not have the details here. In any case we could only go on an average because the cost varies from health board to health board and from institution to institution.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leonard Mr. Leonard
Speaker.P: If it was generally known that health boards require people to accept old people it could well be that the scale would drop and people would be interested in keeping them at a much lower rate than this.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: The CEOs are aware of all this and they have been considering it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leonard Mr. Leonard
Speaker.P: As the Minister is aware the people generally do not know about this. The health boards have not advertised extensively that they require such people.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: That is a matter for the health boards.

Speaker.P: The remaining questions will appear on tomorrow's Order Paper.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Andrews Mr. Andrews
Speaker.P: Has it been decided in relation to the matter on the Adjournment I asked you for on two occasions, Question No. 84 of last Thursday? I wondered how you intended disposing of the time because there may be a number of questions.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: There are a number of questions and the Deputy's query is receiving due consideration. I will communicate with him as soon as possible.

MainHeading.Title: Finance Bill, 1975: Committee Stage (Resumed).
MainHeading.P: Question again proposed: “That section 45 stand part of the Bill.”

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: I do not wish to delay the Minister but he will appreciate that this is Committee Stage and we are making law and in spite of Deputy Esmonde's remarks it is important to look at the legal content. Earlier I said that in substance death duties were not being abolished. I said they were being modified and that death duties were being brought in, without any hiatus in time, under another name, inheritance tax. I also made the point that procedures will remain substantially the same.

I would like to ask the Minister a question about something I am not clear on but which might help me to dispose quickly of the points I want to make. A certificate of inland revenue will be given. Heretofore, a provisional assessment was made at that point and duty was paid on that provisional assessment. A grant did not issue until the duty was paid and the receipt was issued. Can the Minister inform me will the same procedure hold as from 1st April, 1974? Will there be what will amount to a provisional assessment and must that be paid at that stage before a grant, or does the payment of tax wait until the grant is made and the property vests in the successor? This is a point of some importance for the debate. Will the property vest in the successor before payment of any tax or will there be the equivalent of the present position where a provisional assessment is made and tax is payable on foot thereon, correctable later on a final assessment?

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. R. Ryan) Richie Ryan
Speaker.P: The tax will be payable at the point at which the property vests in the beneficiary save in such cases where the Revenue Commissioners have reason to believe that tax might be avoided unless it was collected beforehand. In the vast majority of estates the probate will issue before the payment of capital acquisition tax.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: This is a vital point. A grant may be sought and received before the payment of the tax?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Ryan Mr. Ryan
Speaker.P: Yes.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: I can say without the least hestitation that that is an important reform of the law. Can we take it definitely that that is the position?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: Yes.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: It will no longer be necessary to have a provisional assessment on foot of an inland revenue affidavit before a grant of probate or a grant of administration is issued. At the moment one must have these as primary documents.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: That is right. An executor invariably has to borrow money in order to discharge estate duties prior to the issue of the grant of probate which then confers entitlement to intermeddle with the deceased's estate but in future the liability to pay tax will not arise until after the issue of probate. If, however, in a case where the beneficiary is outside the jurisdiction the Revenue Commissioners would have the obligation to ensure that the liability to tax was not avoided and they would require payment in advance. In so far as people resident here are concerned and the assets are here in the normal course of events the duty will be paid after the issue of the grant.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: In other words the provisional grant assessment is gone?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: There will, of course, have to be an assessment of the value of an estate for probate purposes.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: Of course.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: Somebody has to do that but the question of having to pay tax in advance of probate will not arise except in the circumstances to which I referred.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: In other words, where the property comes into the hands of the successor. It is not clear that the taxable inheritance is in the first instance liable in the hands of the successor but then there are such provisions which I can understand such as section 47 of the Capital Acquisitions Tax Bill which will safeguard the revenue by a lien on the property. The property is chargeable. There are also the portions of the Bill which relate to accountable persons. I asked that question because it affects the analogy with estate duty and it is an important point to be clear on. Although what the Minister said here is not evidence it is certainly evidence of bona fides and I take it that the Minister would not make such a responsible statement unless he was sure of the content of what he has said. This raises the question of what the valuation date is. Is the valuation date to be before or after the grant of probate or letters of administration? Will the Minister answer that?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: With respect, we are getting once more into a debate on the Capital Acquisitions Tax Bill and not the Finance Bill which abolishes death duties.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: I take the Minister's point and if he refuses to give me an answer I will proceed with the point I was making. It was in order to be sure of the situation that I put the question because the Minister has claimed to have abolished estate duty. If the Minister does not wish to answer my question I concede that he has every right not to but it does not help the type of objective discussion I was trying to embark upon.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: There is an important qualification in what the Minister has said. The inheritance tax which Deputy de Valera is rightly contending is another name for death duties is payable on the valuation date and the valuation date in most cases is the date on which the successor becomes entitled to the property which is, in the normal case, before the obtaining of a grant of probate or administration.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: I was given certain answers to my question. They are on the record and I hope are carefully recorded. Those answers have also been heard elsewhere. The Minister contends that estate duty has been abolished and I contend that death duties remain in another guise. I concede the improvements the Minister is making in the Schedule and the reliefs he is giving but they do not amount to the abolition of death duties.

Subsection (1) of section 45 states that estate duty shall not be levied or paid in respect of any property passing or deemed to pass on the death of any person dying on or after the appointed day. The Finance Act of 1894 states:

In the case of every person dying after the commencement of this Part of this Act, there shall, save as hereinafter expressly provided, be levied and paid, upon the principal ascertained as hereinafter provided of all property, real or personal, settled or not settled, which passes on the death of such person a duty, called “Estate duty,” at the graduated rates hereinafter mentioned, and the existing duties mentioned in the First Schedule to this Act shall not be levied in respect of property chargeable with such Estate duty.

MainHeading.P: That is the definition of estate duty. My question is has that been abolished or not? Passing from my contention that in all reality the changing of names with qualifications as to exemptions and application does not amount to an abolition I say that in point of law estate duty is not abolished. If one reads the section I have quoted in connection with subsection (1) of section 45 of the Bill before the House, one will see that that subsection states that after a certain date after the appointed day in respect of any person dying then duty shall not be levied. However, estate duty remains in our law and it is active and applicable to cases before that date. It could not be otherwise without introducing an extraordinary amount of chaos. There is not a scintilla of time hiatus involved in the taxability in principle of all property within the concept of this fiscal law. Therefore, in substance and in fact, estate duty has not been abolished.
I refer again to the Minister's opening remarks in support of that contention. Subsection (2) of section 45 states:

The duties referred to in paragraphs 1, 2, 3 and 4 of the First Schedule to the Finance Act, 1894, shall not be leviable in connection with the death of any person dying on or after the appointed day.
The First Schedule of the Finance Act, 1894 states:

1. The stamp duties imposed by the Customs and Inland Revenue Act, 1881, on the affidavit to be required and received from the person applying for probate or letters of administration in England or Ireland, or on the inventory to be exhibited and recorded in Scotland.

2. The stamp duties imposed by section 38 of the Customs and Inland Revenue Act, 1881, as amended and extended by section 11 of the Customs and Inland Revenue Act, 1889, on the value of personal or moveable property to be included in account thereby directed to be delivered.
3. The additional succession duties imposed by section 21 of the Customs and Inland Revenue Act, 1888.
4. The temporary estate duties imposed by sections 5 and 6 of the Customs and Inland Revenue Act, 1889.
Those referred to in that Schedule as existing duties refer to existing duties.
They are, however, made not to be leviable—and there is a distinction— in connection with the death of any person dying on or after the appointed day. So, there is no abolition there.
Now let us move to subsection (3):

Legacy duty and succession duty shall not be chargeable on a legacy derived from a testator or intestate dying on or after the appointed day nor on a succession conferred on or after the appointed day nor on any other legacy or succession in so far as the duty would, apart from this section, be payable in connection with any event mentioned in subsection (4) of this section.

It is interesting to note that that subsection (3) has some relation to paragraph 5 of the Schedule to the 1894 Act which I have mentioned but there is no need for me to pursue that point. Again, there is a chance here. It is not to be “chargeable” is the word used but of course, if your inheritance tax is limited at all—a thing I dispute—it is in effect another name for your legacy tax.
